1.5.1.title: Overview
1.5.1.content:
Well control events are classified into response levels based on severity and resource requirements. The response level determines:

- Notification requirements
- Resource mobilization
- Management involvement
- External reporting

Response levels may be escalated or de-escalated as the situation evolves.

1.5.2.title: Level 1 - Standard Response
1.5.2.content:
**Definition:**
A well control event that can be managed on-site using standard procedures and personnel.

**Examples:**
- Kick detected and shut in successfully
- Well killed using standard methods (Driller's or W&W)
- Event contained with no escalation
- No injury, environmental impact, or equipment damage

**Actions:**
- Driller initiates shut-in
- Drilling Supervisor takes charge
- Standard kill procedures implemented
- Shore base notified (routine reporting)
- Event documented
- Post-event review conducted

**Notification:**
- OIM notified immediately
- Shore base notified per routine reporting
- Regulatory notification per local requirements

1.5.3.title: Level 2 - Enhanced Response
1.5.3.content:
**Definition:**
A well control event requiring additional resources or expertise beyond normal on-site capability.

**Examples:**
- Standard kill methods unsuccessful
- Stuck pipe during well control
- Equipment malfunction complicating response
- Sustained casing pressure after kill
- Lost circulation during kill
- Potential for escalation identified

**Actions:**
- Level 1 actions plus:
- Shore-based well control support activated
- Additional expertise mobilized as needed
- Management team briefed
- Detailed situation assessment
- Kill plan reviewed with shore support
- Enhanced monitoring implemented

**Notification:**
- Immediate notification to Asset Manager/Operations Manager
- Shore-based well control team activated
- Client/Operator senior management notified
- Regulatory notification as required

1.5.4.title: Level 3 - Major Emergency
1.5.4.content:
**Definition:**
A well control event that has or may result in loss of well control (blowout), serious injury, major environmental impact, or significant asset damage.

**Examples:**
- Uncontrolled flow to surface
- Underground blowout
- Fire or explosion
- Imminent threat to personnel
- Major environmental release
- Structural damage to rig/vessel
- Loss of BOP integrity

**Actions:**
- Personnel safety actions (muster, evacuation if needed)
- Emergency shutdown if required
- All available resources mobilized
- Corporate emergency response team activated
- External emergency services notified as needed
- Media response team on standby
- Full documentation and recording

**Notification:**
- Immediate notification to:
  - Corporate emergency response center
  - Executive management
  - Regulatory authorities
  - Client executive management
- Ongoing situation updates at defined frequency

1.5.5.title: Escalation and De-escalation
1.5.5.content:
**Escalation:**
Response level shall be escalated when:
- Situation worsens despite current response
- Additional resources are needed
- Timeline extends beyond initial estimates
- Complications develop
- Potential consequences increase

When in doubt, escalate. It is better to have resources available and not need them.

**De-escalation:**
Response level may be de-escalated when:
- Situation is stabilized
- Well is under control
- Immediate threat is past
- Reduced monitoring is appropriate

De-escalation requires explicit decision by responsible authority. Maintain heightened awareness during de-escalation.

1.5.6.title: Communication During Events
1.5.6.content:
**On-Site Communication:**
- Driller communicates status to drill floor team
- Toolpusher maintains communication with Driller
- Drilling Supervisor coordinates overall response
- OIM maintains installation-wide awareness
- All communications logged with timestamps

**Shore-Base Communication:**
- Initial notification via quickest means (phone)
- Follow-up with written situation report
- Regular updates at agreed frequency
- Use standard reporting format
- Ensure back-up communication available

**Information to Communicate:**
- Current well status (pressures, volumes)
- Actions taken and planned
- Personnel status
- Equipment status
- Resource requirements
- Timeline estimates

1.5.7.title: Post-Event Actions
1.5.7.content:
Following any well control event:

**Immediate:**
- Verify well is stable and secure
- Account for all personnel
- Assess equipment condition
- Preserve data and records
- Relieve fatigued personnel

**Short-term:**
- Conduct hot debrief with response team
- Document sequence of events
- Identify immediate lessons
- Report per requirements
- Plan resumption of operations

**Longer-term:**
- Formal investigation for Level 2 and 3 events
- Root cause analysis
- Corrective actions identified
- Lessons learned shared
- Procedures updated if needed
- Recognition of effective response
